The Canaanite ethnic identity is better found by looking at the history of the ancient Near East, rather than a religious text. It was long thought, because of the enmity evident in the Bible, that the Canaanites could not be very closely related to the Israelites, although it is evident that both are Semitic peoples. Modern archaeology found that the early Hebrew language was almost identical to the Bronze Age Canaanite language, with no evidence of any Egyptian influence. Archaeologists began to notice continuity between the Bronze Age Canaanite culture and the later Israelite culture, which is puzzling because the Bible tells us that the Israelites virtually exterminated the Canaanites in the Promised Land. That puzzle began to unravel when it was established that the Israelites did not conquer the cities that the Book of Judges reports them as conquering. Historians realised that the Hebrew people did not flee from Egypt as portrayed in the Book of Exodus and did not invade the land of the Canaanites. They must have had a very different origin and they settled peacefully in the Canaanite hinterland, not as conquerors. Having considered the options, historians now say that the Israelites were actually Canaanite people who left the region of the rich coastal cities to settle peacefully in the hitherto sparsely populated hinterland. The Canaanites were ethnically identical to the Israelites and so as to include other ethnic groups of Canaanite origin, including Phoenicians and Aramaeans, are more broadly called North-west Semitic people.
